repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This fixes #27395. OmniSharp (and possibly other LSP servers) can sometimes return a nil value, which rpc.lua chokes on with this error message:

```
Error executing luv callback:                                                                                                                                                                              
...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:410: attempt to index local 'decoded' (a nil value)                                                                                                      
stack traceback:                                                                                                                                                                                                     
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:410: in function 'handle_body'                                                                                                                   
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:761: in function 'handle_body'                                                                                                                   
        ...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:267: in function <...nt_nvimGcA7m0/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/rpc.lua:251>
```

We should not crash, no matter what the LSP server throws at us. Note that #27148 would be even worse; silently ignoring the error. Rather, we should provide a proper error message stating the LSP server gave us something invalid, so that it is clear that the error is with the LSP server, rather than being a crash inside NeoVim runtime scripts. We are already doing a lot of validation in rpc.lua, it's just that nil was being overlooked here.

By adding a check first that `decoded` isn't nil, we end up falling back to the else case:

```
self:on_error(M.client_errors.INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE, decoded)
```

which is going to correctly inform the user that the LSP server is broken, not NeoVim.

comment_data.body: Well, I think instead of such (repetitive) nil checks, we should handle the invalid response and throw early. LSP is not supposed to return a NIL as a RPC response, so if `decoded == nil` then we should raise an error as early as here.

```suggestion
```

The next line says `on_error(M.client_errors.INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE` making this pretty obvious
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -407,7 +407,10 @@ function Client:handle_body(body)
   end
   log.debug('rpc.receive', decoded)
 
-  if type(decoded.method) == 'string' and decoded.id then
+  if type(decoded) ~= 'table' then
+    -- Invalid server message

@@ -407,7 +407,10 @@ function Client:handle_body(body)
   end
   log.debug('rpc.receive', decoded)
 
-  if type(decoded.method) == 'string' and decoded.id then
+  if type(decoded) ~= 'table' then
+    -- Invalid server message

comment_data.body:
actually, I don't think "not being a table" -> "it's null" is very obvious to people reading the error message, who may not be well versed in lua. I also don't think it'll be very obvious that this is where the error is coming from, since INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE is thrown in different places.

I think @MariaSolOs is probably right; people need every hint we can give them when debugging this sort of error, and telling them it's "invalid" is not helpful enough.

However, if others feel strongly we should have just a single INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE, then go ahead and merge as-is.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -407,7 +407,10 @@ function Client:handle_body(body)
   end
   log.debug('rpc.receive', decoded)
 
-  if type(decoded.method) == 'string' and decoded.id then
+  if type(decoded) ~= 'table' then
+    -- Invalid server message

comment_regular_data.body:
You could make this more robust by checking if it's an actual table instead of just not nil.

``` lua
if type(decoded) ~= "table" then
	self:on_error(M.client_errors.INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE, decoded)
elseif --- etc ...
```
@wookayin @icholy I incorporated your improvements. Any else needed to merge this?
is the commit message up to date? the PR description looks like it has useful details that are missing in the commit message

Yes, it's up to date. I would argue what is really relevant is only what is in the commit message, and that the issue linked from it has all the relevant details about the origins of the error and the reasoning behind this way of fixing it. The commit message:

```
fix(lsp): check for nil response from server

this only changes the error message, so that it is clear that
the error is with the LSP server, rather than being a crash inside
NeoVim runtime scripts. We are already doing a lot of validation,
it's just that nil was being overlooked here.

This fixes issue https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/27395
```

However, if you want me to add more to the commit message, be specific and I will.
Slightly unrelated question but this PR makes me wonder: Can we distinguish a decoding error versus a legitimate invalid server response?

> Can we distinguish a decoding error versus a legitimate invalid server response?

We already do; if there was an error decoding the json we get INVALID_SERVER_JSON, whereas nil, although it is valid json, is an invalid server response, and then we get INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE.

But I agree that we should specify further and add "INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NIL" for this case, since it does add some useful information; we want the user to immediately search for why their language server is giving nil, rather than just "something invalid". Please hold on merging until we've changed the messages.

I'm not sure the case of non-nil but still not a table will ever come up, but that could be yet another message: INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NONTABLE. The original "invalid" meant that decoded.method was nil or not a string, that should then also get a specific name: INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NO_METHOD.

> > Can we distinguish a decoding error versus a legitimate invalid server response?
> 
> We already do; if there was an error decoding the json we get INVALID_SERVER_JSON, whereas nil, although it is valid json, is an invalid server response, and then we get INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE.
> 
> But I agree that we should specify further and add "INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NIL" for this case, since it does add some useful information; we want the user to immediately search for why their language server is giving nil, rather than just "something invalid". Please hold on merging until we've changed the messages.
> 
> I'm not sure the case of non-nil but still not a table will ever come up, but that could be yet another message: INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NONTABLE. The original "invalid" meant that decoded.method was nil or not a string, that should then also get a specific name: INVALID_SERVER_MESSAGE_NO_METHOD.

Please don't make this more complex than necessary. The existing error codes are sufficient.

> Please don't make this more complex than necessary. The existing error codes are sufficient.

Agreed, I wasn't suggesting that we add more error codes but I was just wondering if we're able to correctly separate a client-side error (JSON decoding) from a truly misbehaving server.
Either way, changes for that are out of scope for this PR.

title: fix(lsp): check for nil response from server
